Guys one thing worth clarifying is that expressed DNA that does not 
change the phenotype is not the same as useless appendages hanging 
around.  What's interesting about neutral structures in an NN is 
that, assuming they aren't just a bunch of 0-weight connections, 
they perform a function that is either complementary to, redundant 
with, or amounting to no effect on, the rest of the network.  In 
other words it's not junk.  Try inserting a few extra neurons in the 
middle of your brain and see whether is doesn't screw you up.  I 
think it's an accomplishment to add structure that doesn't have a 
deleterious effect.  It's quite analogous to gene duplication in 
nature, which does exactly the same thing and is credited with some 
great accomplishments.  Mathematically, it enters the solution into 
a part of new higher-dimensional space which can now be explored 
safely since it is starting at a robust point, i.e. a point where 
the extra dimensions have been optimized not to interfere with 
normal functionality.  In other words, we shouldn't knock so-
called "redundant" DNA too strongly.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Derek James wrote:
> 
> >On Tue, 01 Jun 2004 22:18:55 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
wrote:
> >  
> >
> >>You're right that culling stagnant species does often give rise 
to
> >>'jumps' in a search. 
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >That was just one possible explanation for fitness jumps following
> >stagnant stretches.  There may be others.
> >  
> >
> Agreed.
> 
> >>But do you agree that some gradual improvements
> >>come about by connecting to neurons that were previously not
> >>contributing to the fitness of a genome. This must be the case 
because
> >>as I said before ALL neurons start out like this. So really the 
question
> >>is not whether redundant structure sometimes gets incorporated, 
but how
> >>much redundant structure gets incorporated and participates in 
the
> >>search process? 
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >I'm not really sure that is the question.  New connections arise, 
but
> >they may be forming new connections to neurons that *were* already
> >doing something useful.  Not all new topological additions are 
linking
> >up redundant structures.
> >  
> >
> I'm still not sure if you've grasped my main point here. Ok so 
sometimes 
> a new connection appears and it immediately increases the fitness 
of a 
> genome - good. But whenever a neuron is added it can *never* be 
> immediately beneficial because NEAT adds them in such a way as to 
make 
> them equivalent to the connection that was split. In order to make 
that 
> neuron useful a further mutation in a later generation must 
connect to 
> that neuron. So therefore this neuron is a very minimal type of 
> redundant structure, I can prove that this redundant structure 
sometimes 
> gets incorporated and made useful because I have seen networks 
that have 
> hidden nodes and these networks are proven to need those hidden 
nodes to 
> do what they do.
> 
> If we establish this as a fact then we can go on to ask - are 
larger 
> redundant structures sometimes incorporated and made useful? and 
not 
> just single neurons?
> 
> >In biology, as far as I understand, more often than not new 
features
> >are coopted from features that already served another adaptive 
purpose
> >(this dynamic is called "exaptation").  It is widely held that
> >feathers first evolved for the purposes of insulation, and were 
later
> >coopted for flight.  Another hypothesis proposes that legs evolved
> >from lateral fins used to help fish that foraged near shores, with
> >dense vegetation and debris, to navigate more easily in such
> >environments (helping them "semi-walk" through or over dense 
aquatic
> >vegetation and push themselves along the river bottom in shallow
> >areas).
> >
> >  
> >
> Ok this really is encroaching on the subjest of indirect 
encodings, 
> which I purposefully put to one side since that's a whole other 
subject.
> 
> >However, you bring up a good point about excess capacity in DNA, 
or
> >junk DNA.  More below...
> >
> >  
> >
> >>I don't think there is really a limit since some small sub-
structure
> >>within a large random network may get connected too and become
> >>beneficial. I think this must happen in nature to some extent 
since DNA
> >>seems so abundant and seems to contain a whole load of junk (not 
proven
> >>though AFAIK, junk DNA could turn out to have a useful and 
direct role).
> >>From that you could conclude that DNA  is cheap to carry around 
and
> >>therefore nature has not much reason to keep it trimmed to a 
minimum,
> >>certainly I think I'm right in saying that there are a lot of 
genes in
> >>the human genome that are from our ancient history and are 
permanently
> >>disabled. 
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >Right...and this is a good point.  NEAT already employs this 
concept
> >with the notion of disabled connection genes.  But there is a 
*huge*
> >difference between carrying around a lot of disabled DNA, as 
opposed
> >to actually expressing all of that DNA in the phenotype.  One is
> >cheap, as you point out...the other is grossly expensive.
> >  
> >
> Yes I see your point. Expressing all of the junk in the phenotype 
may 
> work to some extent but it wouldn't be very efficient. I sort of 
touched 
> on this in the last post when I mentioned that junk structures 
that 
> connect to output nodes would drown out any signals from useful 
> structures. This would be like me having, say, loads of extra 
limbs - 
> the usual four are useful, but start adding extra ones and they 
just get 
> in the way :)
> 
> >So I could be sold that "junk DNA" might be useful, perhaps 
extremely
> >so.  But the idea of a lot of neutral or slightly maladaptive
> >structure expressed in the phenotype, that is just waiting around 
to
> >become useful?  I'm *highly* skeptical that this is a good idea.
> >  
> >
> Yes I agree with this.
> 
> [...]
> 
> >
> >I think the easiest way to mimic junk DNA from biology is to 
simply
> >start with a lot of random genes that are simply not expressed, 
and
> >allow them to collect up during the run.  Although, do you use
> >disabled genes to determine compatibility?  If so, this 
calculation
> >can be computationally expensive, and if you have extremely large
> >genomes that you have to compare every generation, that might be 
an
> >issue.
> >  
> >
> Well my code includes disabled genes in determining compatibility, 
and 
> I'm pretty sure I based this on Ken's NEAT code/papers. Perhaps 
what we 
> need then is some library of structures external to the population 
of 
> genomes. A new mutation could be to randomly insert pieces of 
structure 
> from this library into a genome. That way you get the as-yet-
unproven 
> benefit of 'junk DNA' without the baggage of having to carry it 
around 
> in the genomes. If a useful 'chunk' is found then it then becomes 
part 
> of a genome and subject to propogation through the population 
through 
> the normal means of crossover and asexual reproduction.
> 
> >>Yes that's right. But that is what evolution is all about. The 
vast
> >>majority of the time it comes up with useless structures, and 
every once
> >>in a while (like every few million years or so) something novel 
is
> >>found. 
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >Right...but the useless structures are not generally kept 
around.  You
> >don't see organisms with lots of useless organs or appendages just
> >waiting to become useful.
> >  
> >
> Well that's not entirely true. If the useless appendages hinder 
the 
> organism or require a significant resources to grow and/or 
maintain then 
> individuals with these characteristics will be selected against 
over 
> time. But if the appendages aren't too expensive and aren't 
getting in 
> the way then they can indeed stick around. One that comes to mind 
is the 
> human appendix, and I've never found my little toe to be all that 
> useful. Well Ok you did say 'generally' - these 'extras' are 
mostly 
> special cases. I agree with the general priniciple that organisms 
don't 
> carry around loads of  appendages in the hope that one might 
become 
> useful, like some biological equivalent of a swiss army knife :)
> 
> Colin.
